contentrichtext.text: A '''Koniscope''' (or '''coniscope''') is a [[Measuring instrument|scientific instrument]] to detect and measure content of [[dust]] particles in the [[Earth's atmosphere|atmosphere]].<ref>Storm Dunlop: ''Dictionary of Weather'', ISBN 978-0-19-954144-7 p. 83</ref> A koniscope is also called '''dust counter''', or '''Aitken dust counter''',<ref>[http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=aitken-dust-counter1 American Meteorological Society: Glossary of Meteorology: Aitken dust counter]</ref> named after [[John Aitken (scientist)|John Aitken]] who invented the first koniscope.<ref>[http://travel.webshots.com/photo/2325893050029167518QiychU travel.webshots.com: User oliverjcomo, Science History Tour 2006 -- Part Four (Edinburgh, Siccar Point, Farewell Banquet)]</ref> The koniscope is made by connecting a pump with a [[test tube]] that is walled with moist paper. The tube is held towards a light source and the pump is briefly activated. Dust particles will cling to the paper, producing a visible change in color. ==References== <references/> [[Category:Meteorological instrumentation and equipment]] {{climate-stub}}
